author: Miami Herald
title: Lockheed wins $4.1 bln battle command system contract from US govt
text:
Reuters Lockheed wins $4.1 bln battle command system contract from US govt Read full article Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again later. More content below LMT Reuters April 12, 2024 at 2:06 a.m. · 1 min read In this article: Oops! Something went wrong. Please try again later. More content below LMT
April 11 (Reuters) - Lockheed Martin said on Thursday it had won a contract worth up to $4.1 billion from the U.S. government's Missile Defense Agency to continue the development of its battle command system.
The contract will aim at developing and upgrading the Command and Control, Battle Management and Communications (C2BMC)-Next system.
The C2BMC is a hardware and software interface for the ballistic missile defense system used by the U.S. defense forces for coordinated responses to emerging threats.
"Part of C2BMC-Next will be enhancing global integration, exploring possibilities of linking this decades-long proven, operationally fielded system with allied nations for the first time," the company said.
ADVERTISEMENT The ordering period of the contract is from May 1, 2024 through April 30, 2029, with an option to extend through April 30, 2034.
The defense company added that it will perform the upgradations at a new Huntsville, Alabama facility and Colorado Springs, Colorado. (Reporting by Aatreyee Dasgupta in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

author: Lennart Schwenck
title: „Geschmacklos": Müller-Produkt stößt Kundin auf - Drogeriemarkt zieht Konsequenzen
text:
Eine Müller-Kundin findet ein anzügliches Modellbau-Set in der Spielwarenabteilung. Der Drogeriemarkt reagiert prompt. Auch der Hersteller äußert sich. München – Ein unscheinbares Modellbau-Set erregt aktuell viel Aufsehen: Das Figuren-Set „Voyeure“ der Firma NOCH aus Wangen im Allgäu zeigt halbnackte Frauen, einen Mann mit Fernglas – und ein Kind, das sich die Augen zuhält. Es ist Teil einer Produktreihe für Modelleisenbahn-Landschaften. Das eigentlich unauffällige Set aus dem Standardsortiment wurde zum Zentrum einer hitzigen Debatte über Geschmack, Ethik und die Grenzen der Miniaturdarstellung.
Auslöser für den Wirbel war eine Beschwerde: Christine B. entdeckte das Set in der Spielwarenabteilung einer Müller-Filiale in München. Gegenüber Bild kritisierte sie: „Hier wird Voyeurismus verharmlost und Kindern als harmlose Unterhaltung vermittelt.“ Für sie sei das „nicht nur geschmacklos, sondern auch höchst verantwortungslos.“
Figuren-Set verschwindet nach Beschwerde von Kundin aus dem Müller-Sortiment Der Drogeriemarkt Müller reagierte prompt. Ein Sprecher des Unternehmens erklärte gegenüber der BILD-Zeitung : „Beim Handelskonzern Müller legen wir größten Wert auf ein verantwortungsvolles und familienfreundliches Sortiment. […] Die betreffenden Artikel wurden umgehend entfernt.“ Man bedaure den Vorfall sehr und prüfe derzeit, wie ähnliche Fehler in Zukunft vermieden werden könnten. Das Figuren-Set ist mittlerweile aus dem Sortiment und Online-Handel entfernt worden .
Die Firma Noch GmbH, ein traditionsreiches Familienunternehmen mit 114-jähriger Geschichte und europäischer Marktführerschaft im Bereich Modellbauzubehör, zeigt sich angesichts der Empörung gelassen. Geschäftsführer Rainer Noch erklärte gegenüber dem SWR : „Die Verkaufszahlen haben am Dienstagmorgen schon deutlich angezogen.“ Er rechne damit, dass das Set bald ausverkauft sein werde. Dass gerade dieses Figuren-Set für Diskussionen sorgt, verwundert Noch: „Die Realität kennt keine Tabus, und um ein wirklichkeitsnahes Abbild zu schaffen, ist es notwendig, auch jene Aspekte darzustellen, die zum menschlichen Leben gehören.“ Das Set sei seit Jahren im Sortiment und habe bislang kaum Kritik ausgelöst.
"Gut und günstig": Diese zehn Marken lieben die Deutschen - doch Sieger ist nicht Aldi Fotostrecke ansehen Hersteller äußert sich: „Wir wollen das Leben in all seinen Facetten darstellen“ Das Set „Voyeure“ ist Teil einer Linie von Miniaturfiguren, mit denen Noch laut eigener Website „humorvolle oder ungewöhnliche Szenen“ darstellen will. Im Online-Shop wird es als geeignet für „erotische Szenen in Ihrer Modelllandschaftsgestaltung“ beworben. Die Figuren sind übliche Miniaturfiguren, wie man sie zum Beispiel aus dem Miniaturwunderland in Hamburg kennt. Während kritische Stimmen, wie die von Christine B., das Set als sexualisierte Darstellung mit problematischer Botschaft einstufen, betont der Hersteller seine künstlerische und realitätsnahe Freiheit. „Wir wollen das Leben in all seinen Facetten darstellen,“ sagte Rainer Noch gegenüber dem SWR .
Die Aufmerksamkeit ist für das Unternehmen aus dem Allgäu offenbar kein Nachteil. Bereits auf der Spielwarenmesse in Nürnberg präsentierte die Noch GmbH eine neue Linie namens „Funny-Scenes“, die Sets mit Bezeichnungen wie „Saufbrüder“ , „Seitensprung“ oder „Straßenstrich“ umfasst. Diese sollen ab Oktober im Handel erhältlich sein. Das, was der eine lustig findet, dem anderen sauer aufstößt, ist keine Seltenheit. So erhiet etwa auch ein Mafia-Brettspiel heftigen Gegenwind . ( ls )
Zur Startseite

author: Vinaykumar Patil
title: Congress labelled as Muslim party: Chakravarthy Sulibele slams reversal of Hijab ban in Karnataka
text:
Congress labelled as Muslim party: Chakravarthy Sulibele slams revoke of Hijab ban in Karnataka Namo Brigade's Sulibele criticized Siddaramaiah's government for lifting the hijab ban, alleging Muslim-centric politics and bias. He cited disparities in treatment, questioned educational policies, and financial allocations, accusing the government of creating divisions and suppressing Hindu voices. Sulibele pledged to raise awareness about perceived biases within Hindu society.
Vinaykumar Patil First Published Dec 24, 2023, 9:19 AM IST Follow Chakravarthy Sulibele, a prominent figure associated with the Namo Brigade, launched a vicious attack on Chief Minister Siddaramaiah's government in Karnataka, alleging that the Congress party has transformed into a Muslim-centric political entity. He criticized the recent decision to revoke the hijab ban, suggesting that it's a strategic move to secure Muslim votes, rather than abiding by the law.
Speaking to reporters in the city on Saturday, Sulibele accused Siddaramaiah of showing partiality towards the Muslim community. He emphasized that the government's decision to lift the hijab ban reflects a bias in favour of the Muslim electorate, citing the strategy as a means to gain political mileage.
Hijab ban revoked: BJP leaders criticize Congress government in Karnataka
Sulibele drew parallels with previous governmental decisions, asserting that while Triple Talaq was abolished under Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration, the recent lift on the hijab ban by Siddaramaiah's government unjustly penalizes Muslim girls. He expressed disappointment over the perceived injustice directed towards the Muslim community.
Moreover, he highlighted the potential ramifications of allowing hijabs while potentially restricting other religious attire, anticipating it might foster divisions. He criticized Siddaramaiah's government for what he considered regressive actions, accusing them of undermining educational policies and creating societal discord.
Hijab ban revoked: BJP leaders criticize Congress government in Karnataka
Questioning the financial allocation of ₹10 thousand crores promised to the Muslim community, Sulibele raised concerns over the suspension of scholarships for SC, ST, and OBC students. He criticized the government's direction as detrimental to the state's progress, suggesting it might regress Karnataka's advancements by several decades.
Sulibele denounced what he perceived as the government's suppression of opposing voices, indicating a purported bias against Hindus and their struggles under Siddaramaiah's leadership. He pledged to raise awareness within Hindu society about the perceived bias and urged society to scrutinize the motivations behind the government's decisions.

author: kake.com
title: Walmart recalls magnetic balls after CPSC warns of choking and injury hazards - KAKE
text:
By Ramishah Maruf, CNN
New York (CNN) — Regulators have issued a recall for high-powered magnetic balls after the US Consumer Product Safety Commission issued several warnings for the toy kits, citing the risk of injury or even death.
Walmart recalled the “Relax 5mm Science Kit, Large Hematite Magnets Magnetic Stones Building Blocks,” sold exclusively on the site through Joybuy.
Earlier in December, CPSC said these magnets, often marketed for children, are small enough to fit into the CPSC’s small parts cylinder (which simulates the width of a child’s throat), and are also magnetically stronger than permitted. If swallowed, the high-powered magnets can attract to each other or to other metals inside the digestive system, leading to “perforations, twisting and/or blockage of the intestines, infection, blood poisoning and death.”
The agency broadly estimated 2,500 emergency room visits over magnet ingestions from 2017-2021 and seven deaths, two of which were outside of the United States.
The recall affects about 4,240 units. The CPSC said customers should take away the balls from children immediately and contact Joybuy for a pre-paid label to return the recalled products for a full refund. The toy kit was sold from February 2022 through April 2023 for between $14 and $15 and is made of small magnetic balls in purple, black, green, blue, orange and red.
The-CNN-Wire
™ & © 2023 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.

author: PTI
title: Setback to ruling Congress in Karnataka as temple bill defeated in Legislative Council
text:
BENGALURU: In a setback to the ruling Congress in Karnataka, a bill that sought to collect funds from temples with over Rs 10 lakh annual income was defeated by the opposition BJP-JD(S) combine in the Legislative Council.
The Karnataka Hindu Religious Institutions and Charitable Endowments (Amendment) Bill, 2024 was passed by the Legislative Assembly earlier this week.
It was defeated by a voice vote in the Upper House, where the opposition has a majority, on Friday.
The bill among other things, proposes to collect five per cent from temples whose gross income is between Rs 10 lakh and less than Rs one crore and 10 per cent from temples whose income is above Rs one crore, to be put into a Common Pool Fund, administered by 'Rajya Dharmika Parishath', which is proposed to be used for Archakas' (priests) welfare and upkeep of 'C' category temples (state controlled) whose annual income is less than Rs five lakh.
The act that was earlier amended in 2011 had made way for five per cent of the net income of temples with annual income between Rs five lakh and Rs 10 lakh and 10 per cent of the net income of temples with annual income of over Rs 10 lakh would come to the fund.
The amendment bill had created a huge controversy, as it angered the opposition, especially the BJP, which charged the ruling Congress with trying to fill its 'empty coffers' with temple money, while, the Congress had sought to turn the tables saying the saffron party had effected an amendment in 2011 to seek funds from high-income Hindu shrines.
Leader of the Opposition in Council Kota Srinivas Poojary, who was the Muzrai Minister during the BJP government, while welcoming the move to provide social security to Archakas, opposed diversion of the revenue earned by temples.
He questioned why the government can't provide funds in the budget for their welfare.
The opposition also opposed the proposal in the bill for nomination of the temple committee president by the government.
Muzrai Minister Ramalinga Reddy, trying to convince the opposition, assured the House that the government would not interfere in the nomination of the temple committee president and also to reduce the amount proposed to be diverted from the temples to the common pool.
Highlighting that the bill only proposes minor changes to what the BJP government had proposed in 2011, he said, the intention is the welfare of Archakas at 'C' category temples and the upkeep of such temples.
As the opposition insisted that changes be made to the bill before it is passed, Reddy sought time till Monday, as he needed to discuss it with the Chief Minister Siddaramaiah as it involves financial implications.
However, the Deputy Chairman M K Pranesh, who was in the Chair, did not give time till Monday stating that there is no such provision as the House has already taken up the bill for consideration.
The Bill was subsequently put to vote and it was defeated by the opposition BJP-JD(S) combine.
This is the second such setback to the Congress government in this session, as the BJP and JD(S) combine had referred the Karnataka Souharda Cooperative (Amendment) Bill 2024 to the select committee earlier this week.

author: Momen Zellmi
title: Church of England Embraces Solar Power, Installs 438 Panels on Historic Cambridge Chapel
text:
In an inspiring move towards sustainability, the Church of England has unveiled a significant environmental initiative by installing 438 solar panels on a historic chapel in Cambridge. This groundbreaking project not only showcases the Church's commitment to combating climate change but also sets a precedent for religious institutions worldwide.
Advertisment Embracing Renewable Energy The installation of solar panels on the Cambridge chapel represents a bold step by the Church of England towards embracing renewable energy sources. This initiative is part of a broader environmental strategy aimed at reducing the Church's carbon footprint and promoting sustainable practices among its communities. The choice of a historic chapel for the solar panel display highlights the Church's willingness to integrate modern technology with traditional structures, demonstrating that reverence for the past and responsibility for the future can coexist harmoniously.
Impacts and Achievements Advertisment Since its completion, the solar panel project has garnered attention for its impressive scale and its potential to inspire similar initiatives. By harnessing solar energy, the Church of England is not only reducing its reliance on fossil fuels but also setting an example of environmental stewardship. The initiative echoes the success of the 'Tea and PV' scheme run by the Yorkshire North & East Methodist District, which has seen solar panels installed on church buildings across the Yorkshire coast, powering over 1 million cups of tea and engaging the community in sustainability discussions. These projects collectively underscore the Church's role in leading by example when it comes to renewable energy adoption.
A Call to Action for Global Communities The Church of England's solar panel project on the Cambridge chapel sends a powerful message to communities and institutions worldwide about the importance of taking decisive action against climate change. By integrating renewable energy solutions into its operations, the Church is demonstrating that environmental responsibility is not just a matter of policy but a practical and achievable goal. This initiative invites other religious and secular organizations to consider how they, too, can contribute to a more sustainable future.
The Church of England's decision to install 438 solar panels on a historic chapel in Cambridge is more than an environmental statement; it's a beacon of hope and a call to action. It challenges misconceptions about the compatibility of historical preservation and modern sustainability efforts. As this project gains recognition, it may inspire more institutions to follow suit, potentially leading to a broader societal shift towards renewable energy solutions. The Church's leadership in this area could pave the way for significant progress in the global fight against climate change, proving that faith and environmental stewardship can go hand in hand.

author: MENAFN
title: PM Modi Helped Avert 'Potential Nuclear Attack' In Ukraine: Report | MENAFN.COM
text:
( MENAFN - IANS) New Delhi, March 10 (IANS) An intervention by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and other top leaders helped to prevent a 'potential Russian nuclear attack', CNN reported.
As the Russia-Ukraine war, which broke out in 2022, intensified, the report said, citing two senior officials, that the US started "preparing rigorously" for a potential nuclear strike by Moscow against Kiev.
The Joe Biden administration was "specifically concerned" that Russia might use a tactical or battlefield nuclear weapon, leading to the first nuclear attack since the US dropped bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945, officials said.
It was then that the US sought to enlist the help of India and China to discourage Russia from such an attack.
"US officials say that outreach and public statements from Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi helped avert a crisis," the CNN report stated.
"One of the things we did was not only message them directly but strongly urge, press, encourage other countries, to whom they might be more attentive, to do the same thing," a senior administration official said.
"I think we believe showing the international community concern about this, particularly the concern from key countries for Russia and the Global South, was also a helpful, persuasive factor and showed them what the cost of all this could be," the report said, quoting the official.
Meeting Russian President Vladimir Putin on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Uzbekistan in 2022, PM Modi called for a peaceful solution to the conflict and told the Russian leader that "this is not an era of war".
PM Modi had told President Putin that democracy, diplomacy, and dialogue have kept the world together.
In response, the Russian leader said that he understands India's "concerns" and promised PM Modi that he would try and end the conflict even as he blamed Ukraine for prolonging it.
